egb6qz4.Text: I have a question I hope someone can answer. Why does Venezuela, for example, have to pay a premium for BTC? Shouldn't we want the price to be the same if we want a global currency or store of value?

egaimup.Author: PoolGroup
egaimup.Text:
Am I understanding this right. Mt Gox is reopening and all the bitcoins they had will enter the market. Is this true? If so, don't the rules of supply and demand apply here? Lots of new bitcoins entering, which means more supply? Typically that is a bearish forecast. We would need an increase of trading activity or purchasing power to make it a bullish forecast. 

What is everyone's input on this?

egbie7o.Author: MrRGnome
egbie7o.Text:
By a large margin? It's a single peak caused almost entirely by 1 sat/byte transactions that is only 10k transactions over the previous peak in the 30 day timespan. If you move out even further to 3 months it's not even the highest peak anymore.

Why are you raising the alarms?

egayju2.Author: AussieBitcoiner
egayju2.Text: I highly doubt consensus could be achieved for a block reduction

egb3qsa.Author: 46dcvls
egb3qsa.Text:
It's almost certainly never going to have consensus , so no this isnt going anywhere.

If pools want to set their limit at 300kb nothing is stopping them. If nodes want to not accept blocks over 300kb , nothing is stopping them. The current observed reality is the state of consensus.

If a subset of users want to fork off to a chain that only recognizes 300kb max blocks, they are free to do so at any time, but will find themselves on a tiny minority chain with almost no hashrate and will be easily open to attacks.

egb905t.Author: MrRGnome
egb905t.Text: Luke is an engineer. His thoughts are very valid from that perspective. But those thoughts will never find consensus as evidenced by the big block fight, so it's kind of a moot point. I think it was Newbery who said something like "Luke has a way of being right but in a way that is certain to piss everyone off"

egbcoqa.Author: jesuisbitcoin
egbcoqa.Text: I think Luke is being very smart here, it may be a way to protect the current 1MB block size limit in the long term : asking for 300KB shifts the debate to the lower side and the current limit is more likely to be viewed as a reasonable compromise (which I think it is).

egbxbzt.Author: 0delta
egbxbzt.Text: Coinbase Pro has 0 fee and tight spreads if you can pass verification and use limit orders.

egb75yx.Author: noneither
egb75yx.Text:
Supply and demand.  It's restricted in Venezuela so the supply is not liberally available. 

It's also hard to get a price for anything when there are regulated exchange rates.

egbbchp.Author: curseknight
egbbchp.Text: Like the other replier said. If I try to charge you $10 for a bottle of water, you'll think it's expensive, but if the transaction happens in a desert, you'll think it's a bargain! Similarly, fiat in Venezuela is shit which makes BTC extremely desirable (the bottle of water in the desert) and naturally hard to get. To make it worse, it's restricted there (it's a desert). There you have it.

Will the people that held 20 BTC on MtGox at $300 each sell them now for $3500? your guess is as good as anyone elses.

egald58.Text: I'm pretty sure there was news the other day that showed that a lot of Mt Gox coins were sold onto the market starting in Dec of 2017 and all the way through 2018 which is what caused the steep decline in price. And I think the 2 guys that did it are done selling now so that should be bullish. That's a short summarization from my bad memory but you could look it up.

egc1wa2.Author: benziebawks
egc1wa2.Text: A Bart is when the price spikes, then slightly goes up and down for a while, the falls sharply.  Thus creating a pattern resembling the head of Bart Simpson.  Bitcoin's way of telling us - Eat my shorts.

egbd9j7.Text: Great explanation! Many people do not fully grasp the dire straights that the economy of Venezuela is currently in.

egbtyba.Author: Nursing_guy
egbtyba.Text: You are confusing global currency with global market. Even in a global market local conditions affect local prices. Since the conditions in the USA mean that we always have access to an exchange all prices have to compete on the free market with that exchange. In Venezuela they do not have access to the exchange so the price reflects that lack of competition squeezing on the supply. This affects all asset based global markets.

egbxmiu.Author: curseknight
egbxmiu.Text: It's true that BTC's market value is in sync across most of the world, but not every country has easy means of acquisition of BTC (e.g. exchange services), not every government accepts it, and not every country has stability in fiat. These are some of the factors that create a closed market with a higher price than the answer you get on Google when you type "bitcoin price".

egbxy6m.Author: curseknight
egbxy6m.Text: In Venezuela, fiat is shit. Bitcoin represents a safe haven to them (although it's NOT a safe haven), and freedom from the slimy hands of their "government" (cannot be seized).
